title: 104_hr4111
content: The Act titled "Federal Law Enforcement Dependents Assistance Act of 1996" provides educational assistance to dependents of slain federal law enforcement officers. It amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to include educational benefits for dependents of civilian federal law enforcement officers killed or disabled in the line of duty. The purpose of the "Federal Law Enforcement Dependents Assistance Act of 1996" is to provide educational assistance to dependents of civilian Federal law enforcement officers who are killed or disabled in the line of duty. This includes enhancing the appeal of service in these agencies, extending higher education benefits to deserving individuals who may not afford it otherwise, and helping family members achieve the educational status they would have attained if not for the officer's death or disability. Eligibility criteria are outlined in the Act. The "Federal Law Enforcement Dependents Assistance Act of 1996" provides financial assistance to dependents of eligible Federal law enforcement officers for education. Assistance is given to children or spouses of officers in case of death or disability. The duration of benefits is limited to forty-five months of full-time education. Dependent children must be under 27 years old to be eligible for assistance. Applications for assistance are subject to approval by the Attorney General. The Attorney General requires an application for assistance under the Federal Law Enforcement Dependents Assistance Act of 1996. Approval is granted unless the dependent is ineligible, the educational institution doesn't meet requirements, the program doesn't meet criteria, or the dependent is already qualified. The Attorney General notifies the dependent of approval or disapproval. The Attorney General notifies a dependent of approval or disapproval in writing for assistance under the Federal Law Enforcement Dependents Assistance Act of 1996. The Attorney General has the authority to create regulations for implementing a specific subpart. Assistance under this subpart may be discontinued if the recipient fails to maintain satisfactory progress according to the standards of the educational institution. SEC. 1216. SPECIAL RULE. Dependent of a Federal law enforcement officer killed in the line of duty on or after May 1, 1992, eligible for retroactive and prospective assistance under this subpart. Retroactive assistance applies to education pursuit at eligible institutions, subject to limitations. Dependent may waive retroactive assistance and opt for prospective assistance. The term 'Attorney General' refers to the US Attorney General. 'Federal law enforcement officer' has the same meaning as in subpart 1. 'Program of education' includes coursework necessary for a specific educational or vocational goal. 'Eligible educational institution' is defined as an institution described in the Higher Education Act of 1965 and eligible for federal programs. The curr_chunk states that an individual must meet certain criteria to be eligible for programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the implementation of programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965.
